text:
Someone asked me this question recently at an AMA: 
How does the data governance coming from Congress and even President Trump impact how big tech companies like Google, Meta, and OpenAI are developing their models? 
(Thanks for your question, Eashan Kosaraju.)

Here's the video of my answer: https://lnkd.in/ewQy9-6Z

Here's the written version: 
Generally, it makes good financial sense for big companies to follow laws and regulations. 
So when we see sweeping legislation passed, companies will usually comply. 
But when regulation is designed to be "one and done"—as if we can solve it once and never revisit it—that's where I start to worry. 
That approach can have unintended consequences.

Personally, I prefer incremental governance, especially when dealing with complex systems whose long-term effects are difficult to predict. 
If data governance has a one-size-fits-all mindset to "future-proofing" then we won't be future-proof. 
Sweeping legislation can restrict the best outcomes we might otherwise see from these companies.

I spent nearly a decade at Google, and I genuinely believe that making the world’s information universally accessible and useful is a powerful mission. 
But if we overregulate, we risk losing a lot of the good that comes from that work.

At the same time, information can clearly be misused. 
I agree with Congressman Jay Obernolte's take that "it’s already illegal for someone to steal your money—we don’t need a new law making it illegal to use AI to do it." 
The issue often isn’t about inventing new laws, but enforcing the ones we already have, particularly when it comes to data privacy violations and leaks.

These huge companies have a huge responsibility. 
They must be careful stewards of data, not just because governments say so, but because their long-term success depends on it. 
In fact, I’d argue that the internal incentives for handling data responsibly are often stronger than what external regulation can enforce.

Back when I was at Google, friends and family used to speculate about the company doing all kinds of sketchy things with data. 
And I’d think, “If that were true—my job as a data scientist would’ve been so much easier.” 
The truth is, there's already a strong culture of caution around data in many of these organizations.

So yes, governments play an important role. 
But I’d urge caution for any government that wants to pass a single set of sweeping policies, call it done, and then expect those policies to hold up forever. 
That’s not how complex systems work.

https://lnkd.in/ewQy9-6Z

Vibe coding, a term coined by Andrej Karpathy in February 2025, describes an increasingly popular approach to writing software: 
Express the code you want in a few sentences to an AI system like ChatGPT or Claude, then polish and (hopefully!) test the generated result.

Two things you should know:
1) Vibe coding isn't new, but the name is.
2) Vibe coding doesn't eliminate work—it just shifts it from writing to explaining and reviewing... which isn't always a win.

With vibe coding, you're playing archeologist in someone else's mistakes. 
For better or worse.

In my newsletter, I walk you through an example and present the case for vibe coding and the case against it, analyzed from the POVs of the novice and the expert. 
Read my full explanation here: https://lnkd.in/e4_RS4fD

#AI
#vibecoding
#technology
#GenAI
#software
#programming
#coding

If you found this useful, a repost and follow makes my heart happy.

Agree or disagree with this wall I'm standing in front of?

"If you think technology will solve your problems then you don't understand technology - AND you don't understand your problems."

Art by Laurie Anderson (Four Talks installation at the Hirshorn Museum of Art in Washington DC, 2020)

Another quote: "Books are the way the dead talk to the living."

A follow/repost to encourages more posts like this, an ignore to discourage them. 
Your move.

♟️♟️ ♟️ The bughouse chess matchups have been announced! ♟️ ♟️ ♟️
Garry Kasparov vs Cassie Kozyrkov
Lauren Lyons vs Steve Wozniak

Prepare to be crushed, Garry!

Bughouse is a paired game, so which team are you going to bet on and why?
♟️Wozniak+Kozyrkov♟️ or ♟️Kasparov+Lyons♟️

Choose wisely!

Just kidding, that's the headlining speakers list for #MobileWorldCongress in Barcelona! 
These posters are on every streetlamp on so many streets all over the city, which is something I'll never get used to. 
I'll be on the mainstage Wednesday with 24,000 people signed up for the event. Woohoo!

But, while we're making chess noises, please enjoy this ultra-throwback puppy face photo of me at a bughouse game taken more than half my life ago, back when I was a college senior. 
Plus another chess photo from DLD Conference 2024. 
100% guarantee Garry would crush me, though.

Come say hi after my fireside chat on Wednesday hosted by Pipo Serrano, since I'll be milling about as usual outside the auditorium in case folks want to stop by. 
Or come say hi in the comments! 
Or... why not both?

Chess credits:
In the college photo, I'm playing against Alex Lo, the friend who taught me bughouse in the first place and is therefore responsible for any problems I later may cause with it.*
In the DLD24 photo, I'm playing against Tunde Onakoya, the grandmaster who holds the Guinness World Records for the longest marathon chess game.

#MWC25 #keynote #AI

* We may also be inclined to blame Sean Mason, Arda Kutlu, and/or Eric Wheeler, who can be seen about to cause trouble on adjacent boards.

AI only sees the past, not the future.
AI only sees the pattern, not the purpose.
AI only sees the data trail, not the human story.
AI only sees compliance, not commitment.
AI only sees keyword matches, not understanding.
AI only sees what you wrote, not what you thought.
AI only sees message response times, not friendship.
AI only sees your calendar events, not what they mean to you.
AI only sees what was implemented, not what was considered.
AI only sees the final decision, not bolts of inspiration.
AI only sees what worked before, not what will work next.
AI only sees what you did, not why you did it.
AI only sees your digital shadow, not the real you.

If you liked this, please give me a follow to encourage me to make more like it. 
Or, if you already follow me, tell a friend. ✨

🇪🇺 Dear Europe, now that you've made it 🤯illegal🤯 this week to give your workforce AI tools without training employees in #AI #literacy... 
Who's going to do that for you?

When it comes to AI, not so many folks can both talk and understand what they're talking about. 🦸‍♀️

I trained over 20,000 Googlers to help Google go AI-First and I'm here if you need me.

Reach out: https://makecassietalk.com

The U.S. Copyright Office has spoken!

Your Creative Edits = ✅ Copyrightable
Your Creative Edits + AI Output = ✅ Copyrightable
Unedited AI Output = ❌ Not Copyrightable
Your Prompts + Unedited AI Output = ❌ Not Copyrightable

Here's the actual text from their published PDF: https://lnkd.in/ev2bv2Hv

🤖 The use of AI tools to assist rather than stand in for human creativity does not affect the availability of copyright protection for the output.
🤖 Copyright protects the original expression in a work created by a human author, even if the work also includes AI-generated material.
🤖 Copyright does not extend to purely AI-generated material, or material where there is insufficient human control over the expressive elements.
🤖 Whether human contributions to AI-generated outputs are sufficient to constitute authorship must be analyzed on a case-by-case basis.
🤖 Based on the functioning of current generally available technology, prompts do not alone provide sufficient control.

The LinkedIn autoplay feature is a funny one. 
If you let this video play without clicking on it, the views don't get counted. 😿 
So if you found this take on GenAI useful, please give it a little clickity click through to YouTube. 
Thank you, thank you!

Hang on a moment! 👀 
When we use the "temporary chat" setting in ChatGPT, OpenAI promises not to use our prompts to train its #genai models directly... but what about indirectly? 
Might they still be harvesting insights via their #datascience teams?

If you're a #legal professional with expertise in data use policies, pretty please weigh in! 
(For the rest, please tag/fwd to your favorite knower of tech law.)

Because that would be one hell of a powerful dataset, especially if people don't realize there's a difference! 
What would you do with the dataset of all the prompts people made when they thought no one was watching? 👀
